issue.title: [ENH] Adding "fit" parameters to VAR constructor #1850

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look
at our contribution guide: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
Reviewed and added missing statsmodel's parameters to non-constructor or fit functions

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
Four statsmodel-based files were reviewed/worked on. These are: 

* var.py - added `freq`, `dates` and `ic` parameters
* trend.py - no change, all parameters matched with statsmodel
* theta.py - no change needed
* structural.py - no change needed
* ets.py - no change needed

Refer to docstrings in the constructors for their uses.

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?
It does not introduce a new dependency

#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?
In ets.py, `method` is called in the `super().fit()` method of class `ETSModel`. This is originally from class 'LikelihoodModel' - Solved

#### Any other comments?

##### For all contributions
- [ ] I've added myself to the [list of contributors](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/.all-contributorsrc).
- [ ] Optionally, I've updated sktime's [CODEOWNERS](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CODEOWNERS) to receive notifications about future changes to these files.
- [*] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally.

##### For new estimators
- [ ] I've added the estimator to the online documentation.
- [ ] I've updated the existing example notebooks or provided a new one to showcase how my estimator works.


<!--
Thanks for contributing!
-->

body: 😄 @fkiraly Looks interesting! Sure, I will take on this work
I'd like to get started on adding SARIMAX functionality to sktime if you haven't already worked on that part @biologioholic! Please let me know, and I can get started right away.
Hello @ryali1, I'm already half way through Sarimax. Debugging atm

Hi @biologioholic, that sounds good, appreciate your response! Have you worked on AutoReg already? If not, maybe I could get started on that. I'm still familiarizing myself with contributing to sktime, so maybe we could collaborate on this, or I could come to you with questions about how to properly test/debug the code I write with the sktime framework?

Sure, you can go ahead and do the AutoReg. You can look at sktime/forecasting for some interface examples

https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/tree/main/sktime/forecasting

Great! I'll get started on the AutoReg functionality. I'll start with creating a separate estimator as @fkiraly mentioned and will get feedback on it before working on step 2 (getting VAR to default to it).
@fkiraly SARIMAX.py is in testing phase. I have test_sarimax.py in  sktime/forecasting/tests and it works locally. How can I include it in pytest so that it becomes a part of check_estimator?

issue.title: [ENH] Added SARIMAX interface for sktime

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look
at our contribution guide: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
<!--

Please use keywords (e.g., Fixes) to create link to the issues or pull requests
you resolved, so that they will automatically be closed when your pull request
is merged. See https://github.com/blog/1506-closing-issues-via-pull-requests
-->
Reference [Issue#2357](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2357#issue-1188669260)

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you have implemented.
-->
- Implemented `SARIMAX` in sktime/forecasting
- Implemented `test_sarimax` in  sktime/forecasting/tests

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?

<!--
If your contribution does add a new hard dependency, we may suggest to initially develop your contribution in a separate companion package in https://github.com/sktime/ to keep external dependencies of the core sktime package to a minimum.
-->

No, it does not introduce a new dependency

#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?

<!-- This section is particularly useful if you have a pull request that is still in development. You can guide the reviews to focus on the parts that are ready for their comments. We suggest using bullets (indicated by * or -) and filled checkboxes [x] here -->
- Simple tests show good agreement between sktime sarimax and statsmodel sarimax, but need more sophisticated testing.
- Need more testing regarding exog input or different combination of seasonal order.

#### Any other comments?
<!--
Please be aware that we are a loose team of volunteers so patience is necessary; assistance handling other issues is very welcome. We value all user contributions, no matter how minor they are. If we are slow to review, either the pull request needs some benchmarking, tinkering, convincing, etc. or more likely the reviewers are simply busy. In either case, we ask for your understanding during the review process.
-->
- Any additional comment is appreciated. 
#### PR checklist
<!--
Please go through the checklist below. Please feel free to remove points if they are not applicable.
-->

##### For all contributions
- [*] I've added myself to the [list of contributors](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/.all-contributorsrc).
- [*] Optionally, I've updated sktime's [CODEOWNERS](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CODEOWNERS) to receive notifications about future changes to these files.
- [*] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally.
- [*] The PR title starts with either [ENH], [DOC] or [BUG] indicating wether the PR topic is related to enhancement, documentation or bug

##### For new estimators
- [ ] I've added the estimator to the online documentation.
- [ ] I've updated the existing example notebooks or provided a new one to showcase how my estimator works.


<!--
Thanks for contributing!
-->
